alert.note: Alert for Lewis (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 9:49PM PST until March 01 at 7:46AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington... Chehalis River Above Doty affecting Lewis County. Chehalis River Above Grand Mound affecting Grays Harbor and Thurston Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington... Newaukum River Near Chehalis affecting Lewis County. .Heavy rain over the Central and Southern Cascades will continue into Tuesday morning. The rain will taper off later Tuesday morning into Tuesday afternoon. Temperatures in the lower and mid levels in the mountains are above freezing adding a little snow melt to the runoff. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Chehalis River Above Doty. * WHEN...Until tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 318.0 feet, flood waters of the upper Chehalis and South Fork Chehalis will inundate many roads and some residential and commercial areas. Impacted roadways and surrounding areas include Curtis Hill...Lake Creek...Moon Hill...Wildwood Roads in the Boisfort Valley and Labri Rd. and Front St. below Doty. This stage roughly corresponds to just below Phase 2 in the Lewis County flood system. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 PM PST Monday the stage was 318.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 PM PST Monday was 318.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is cresting now at 318.1 feet. The river will fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 318.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by Tuesday morning at 600 AM PST.
